results.title: I know an old lady who swallowed a fly
results.creator_credit: Derek Lamb, Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A nonsense song, sung by Burl Ives and given unrestrained interpretation by the cartoonist. Of course, by the time the song ends the old lady has swallowed much more than a fly. Written by Canadian folksinger Alan Mills. (Awards: Santa Barbara; Chicago; Gottwaldov)

results.title: I just work here
results.creator_credit: Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Shows how customer service can be improved when the person providing the service makes an extra effort to understand the customer’s point of view and does not rigidly adhere to the rules.

results.title: I Is for important
results.brief_description: The film covers examples of sex role stereotyping in social interaction and emotional expression in schools. The scenes include sex role bias in disciplinary actions and student task assignments and children’s resistance to role reversal in kindergarten play.

results.title: I have Turkish blood in my body, how can I put it off? (TEFC)
results.brief_description: An interview with two Turkish girls living in Australia which highlights family life in Turkish culture in comparison to Anglo Australian family life. Further it demonstrates clearly the substantial differences between sub-groups in the Turkish community.

results.title: I give my heart
results.creator_credit: Gillian Coote, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Working series”.
Tells the story of Ulla, a volunteer worker for the Laotian refugees coming into Australia. Ulla, having experienced growing up under Hitler, is committed to helping humanity. She works about ten to twelve hours a day but still doesn’t have enough time to finish her work. She is hopeful of forthecoming government assistance.

results.title: I dream of peace and rest: Norman Lindsay
results.brief_description: The opening of Norman Lindsay’s house by the National Trust. The house exhibits work by Norman Lindsay, including sculpture in the gardens. Lindsay’s thoughts and reflections on his life and work are heard, and many of his works of art are shown. Narrated by Margaret Throsby and Don Reid.

results.title: I don't have to work that big
results.creator_credit: Michael McKennirey, John Smith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “West”.
Joe Fafard knows cows - the way they tuck in their forelegs to lie down and ruminate, the way a calf romps in the barnyard. He also knows people - all his friends and neighbors of the farming community of Pense, Saskatchewan. And he sculpts them all, in clay, in eloquent little miniatures. Joe’s work has been exhibited throughout western Canada as well as in Paris and New York. Here you see what he does.

results.title: I do and I understand
results.creator_credit: Derek Williams, John Arnold, Graphic Films and Nuffield Foundation

results.title: I didn't know you could tie
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
A child is assisted by the teacher to clarify her feelings about another child sho is engaged in an independent activity. The child’s inappropriate criticism is mildly reprimanded.

results.title: I am Joe's heart
results.brief_description: While the camera follows Joe through a typical American business man’s day, his heart speaks out about what Joe is doing to it. Animation in a machinery metaphor illustrates the heart’s functions and the effects upon it of anxiety, tension, smoking, faulty diet and overweight. Joe’s heart attack and a coronary shutdown are detailed along with the step-by-step lifesaving procedures in an Intensive Care Unit. While Joe’s recovery lessens the fear of the fatality of a heart attack his experience brings home a lesson that can prevent heart attacks from happening.
